notes:
Company email (September 2011):
"No animal products are used to produce the Casal Garcia rosé wine."

Company email after being asked to consider vegan alternatives by Patricia:
"We have really appreciated your inputs and would like to let you know that we are already doing some tests with vegetable gelatins as alternatives to the products we are using. Maybe soon we may have alternatives and good news for you!"

Company email:
"Casal Garcia uses gelatin in the processing of the product.

Company email (January 2015):
"Thank you for your interest in our Bogle 2012 Old Vine Zinfandel.  I just checked with our Associate Winemaker, and that specific wine was not fined with egg whites."

Company email (October 2014):
"We do not use any animal based products in our production other than egg whites.  The egg whites are only used in a case by case basis depending on the astringency level of a particular vintage.  However if you enjoy drinking our white wines, you can continue, as we would never fine a white wine with egg whites.  I checked with our winemaker on newer red vintages that did not use egg whites, I will leave the list below.  Please let me know if you have any other questions, cheers!
 
Vegan Red’s/No Egg Whites
2012  Petite Sirah
2012  Essential Red
2012  Cabernet Sauvignon
2012  Merlot
2012  Pinot Noir
 
All white wines are vegan, no egg whites added.
 
2011 Phantom HAS egg whites, not vegan."

Company email (November 2013):
"In fact, there are no animal products used in any of our current vintages with the only exception being our 2011 Essential Red.  Egg whites were used in the fining process, however no trace is left after repeated filtering and final bottling.  So feel free to enjoy the wines as you have in the past, perhaps just avoiding the Essential Red."

Company email:
"Bogle winemakers use several products in the production of our wines, including gelatin and egg whites.  These are classic and standard materials used in the making of most wines in California today."

Company email (January 2013):
"All of our white wines are vegan.  All of our reds are fined with egg whites, so they are not.  None are processed anywhere else other than our winery in Hopland which is certified organic (not that that really matters for this specific question)."

Company email (December 2012):
"In response, while we do offer our various product lists, some products in our stores and the selections offered may actually vary somewhat by state and region. The primary reason for this is that we also attempt to source products locally whenever we can, as we also do not ship our products over really long distances.  Our lists are also not all-inclusive, and are offered moreso as a guideline of possible product selections.  

"In response, while we do offer our various product lists, some products in our stores and the selections offered may actually vary somewhat by state and region. The primary reason for this is that we also attempt to source products locally whenever we can, as we also do not ship our products over really long distances.  Our lists are also not all-inclusive, and are offered moreso as a guideline of possible product selections.  

In response, to your inquiry regarding our possible vegan wine options, we are enclosing a list of possible vegan wine selections below:

Bonterra-Whites are vegan	
Castle Rock-All are vegan	
Charles Shaw-Reds are vegan *occasionally gelatin is used in the whites' refining processes, but that it is removed from the end product
Cline Cellars-All are vegan	
Fetzer-Whites are vegan	
Georges Dubeouf-All are vegan	
Kendall Jackson-Whites are vegan	
Rosenblum Cellars-All are vegan"

Our previous entry was based on feedback from a restaurant, but Jenna set us straight - it's always best to go to the source:
"One of the wine companies most widely known to be vegan, Bonterra, actually uses egg whites in their fining. You should take them off your wine list and even consider running a blurb - Native Foods, Herbivore, and a ton of other vegan restaurants sell or have sold them, and tons of vegans I know like to drink it. Their white wines are vegan, but their red wines are NOT. I just got off the phone with James Caudill, one of their reps, and he confirmed it."

Seconded by Mo - company email:
"We use egg whites in the fining process of our red wines. However, our white wines are free of any animal products and are vegetarian and vegan friendly.  Ages ago, it was discovered that egg whites added to wine would aid in removing unwanted tannins. This 'tannin fining' process is used to improve the flavor of red wines by limiting the astringency caused by the tannins. The egg whites settle to the bottom and are then filtered out. All residue of the egg whites is removed from the wine."

Company email (August 2014):
"We do use a bit of casein in our Pinot Blanc, but other than that nothing!"

Company Email:
"Byron and IO red wines would qualify as vegan.  The Byron whites have had casein additions here and there over the years which would disqualify them...."

Company email (May 2012):
"I confirm you that Distilleria Bottega products (Wine, grappas and liquors - except for milk cream like Fior di latte or Latte Macchiato or other liquors that specifically contain animal ingredients well descripted in ingredients list) don't contain any animal ingredients or additives (expecially those used in wine filtration)."

976401.product_name: Bottega Vino dei Poeti Prosecco Extra Dry

notes:
Company email:

According to our winemaker you will have to give the white wines a skip. Avoid the Goats do Roam and the Pinotage, as we buy in some wine for these, and am not sure what they have done to it. All the other red wines are safe for you to enjoy.

Company email (September 2014):

"I am afraid to let you know that there are some wines that we have used products containing eggs to filter them, though this is a very expensive treatment. But because of this reason and because we are aware of vegan consumers we are starting to stop this use of products, as you may know some of our wines are from past vintages and have been already bottled so those are the wines my colleague Juan Ignacio was talking about. For  next vintages you will be able to try our wines because they will be with no traces of this kind of products!

Our Vegan Friendly Wines arriving into Dan Murphy’s by the end of this year:

Zuccardi Serie A Bonarda 2013
Zuccardi Serie A Malbec 2013
Zuccardi Serie A Chardonnay Viognier 2013"

Note from Danielle (June 2014):
"Unfortunately I didn't see the "this product has been made with the aid of egg..." until after I'd purchased it. This is the 2011 Serie A Malbec." [If you would like to see a copy of the picture of the label, please email contact@barnivore.com.]

Company email (February 2014):
"All our wines nowadays are vegan friendly. We don't use any animal products or derivatives."

Company email (January 2011)
"Our wines DO NOT contain any animal ingredients or animal products.
For filtration, we use mechanic procedures and mineral materials (like bentonite) sometimes"

Company email (November 2010)
"Ian, our Wines are 100% vegan-friendly"

Company email (October 2010)
"We only use bentonite (it's a mineral) for fining our wines. Our wines are vegan."

Company email (February 2014):
"Only our 2011 Cabernet has been fined with egg white. Everything else on our list is vegan friendly. So Primitivo is definitely fine for you."

Company email (May 2013):
"Vegan Wines:
Glimmer of Hope Shiraz (2008, 2010, 2011)
Organic Chardonnay (2012)
Viognier (2009)"

969201.product_name: Kangarilla Road The Cul de Sac 2012

notes:
Company email (February 2014):
"It is only on the Kadette range that we use some fining products, but the Pinotage, Cabernet Sauvignon and Paul Sauer are all suitable."

Company email (February 2014): re: Vintner's Reserve Merlot (2010)
"VR Merlot is suitable for Vegans – all vintages"

Company email (February 2014): re: Vintner's Reserve Pinot Noir (2011) and Vintner's Reserve Zinfandel (2011)
"Our Pinot Noir and Zinfandel are absolutely  Vegan suitable.  They were not fined using any animal products or derivatives.  Please feel free to enjoy!"

Company email (January 2009):
"We do not use egg whites or isinglass to fine any of our white wine. We use egg white on occasion (rarely) to filter red wine.  Our winemaker says that when you filter, often you are filtering out flavor as well, and so he doesn't often use this process."

Company email (June 2007):
"Kendall-Jackson may use one of the following as a fining agent in its red wines:
Egg whites
Sturgeon bladder
Gelatin
These fining agents are used to soften tannins from the seeds and grapes prior to bottling.  After the agents react with the wine, they are racked away and there should be no residue left in the final product.
The above-listed fining agents are not used in our white wines, as the grapes are pressed immediately upon arrival and there is minimal contact between the juice, seeds and skins."

Company email (February 2014):
"You’ll be glad to know that all of our reds at Langmeil are vegan friendly and we are trialling a potato derived protein on some whites which could replace gelatine as a juice fining agent. Unfortunately the milk products are harder to avoid for whites but we’re working on it."

5159801.product_name: Langmeil Three Gardens Shiraz Grenache Mourvèdre 2010

notes:
Company email:
"our Beaujolais wines are never fined, therefore they never contain egg traces, which is not the case for our Côte d'Or wines (fined with egg whites), there are therefore adapted to vegans."

Company Email:
"We forwarded your request to our wine expert in Italy, who confirmed
that all our wines do not contain animal ingredients and no animal
products are used during the production process, since 2009."

1807601.product_name: Mionetto Prosecco Superiore Valdobbiadene Rive di Santo Stefano Millesimato Brut

notes:
Company email (August 2011): 

"The wine are all manufactured on site and the only animal product used is Ichtyocolle (fish based and equivalent to isinglass) when fining the whites. The reds are not fined. We do not use any other animal products."

Company email (August 2011): 
"100% of our Pinots are “Vegan” and are made without the use of any animal products. Most of the Chardonnays are finned with isinglass, and thus do not qualify as Vegan. We produce 100% of our wines in our Sonoma winery and control the process from grape to bottle."

2155701.product_name: Patz and Hall Jenkins Ranch Pinot Noir 2012

notes:
Company email (February 2014):
"Louisa our winemaker, has just informed me that she has been making the wines deliberately vegan since 2008."

Company email (February 2013):
"If you are looking for a vegan-friendly Port you can choice the Sandeman Vintage (all vintage crops) and Sandeman LBV.

All the other range is treated (fined) with gelatin from animal origin. Hope in the future we can use only vegetal gelatin.

Sandeman Ports are exclusively produced and bottled in Portugal."

Company email:
"Company Email: June 2010
"At Schug, we use a minimal amount of gelatin and/or isinglass in fining our whites, so they are not Vegan friendly. 

However, our sparkling wine, rose and all our current (and near future) red wines are vegan friendly.  (We produce 3 different Pinot Noirs, 2 Merlots, 2 Cabernet Sauvignons, a Cabernet Franc and a Syrah)""

Email Direct from Winery
"All Schug current release red wines are Vegan.  No animal products are used
in the processing/filtration of these wines.

Schug’s Rouge de Noirs is the same.

Schug white wines are fined using animal products.

Schug’s rose wine is Vegan."

9359301.product_name: Schug Carneros Heritage Reserve Pinot Noir 2007

notes:
Company email (April 2012):
"The 2009 MOMO Pinot Noir is vegan-friendly – it contains no animal products. There are no other places where our MOMO Wines are made other than right here in Marlborough, so this will be true of all the 2009 MOMO Pinot Noir.
 
The only animal product we use for some wines in some vintages is Gelatine, but none of this was used in the 2009 MOMO Pinot Noir.
 
The 2011 MOMO Chardonnay, 2011 MOMO Pinot Gris, 2009 MOMO Riesling are also vegan friendly. The 2010 MOMO Sauvignon Blanc used gelatine, but the certified organic 2011 MOMO Sauvignon which we will release shortly did not."

Note from Tanysha (November 2014):
"These are all 100% vegan"

Company email (March 2014):
[Clarification regarding Red Knot wines] "In the past we had used egg white (a very ancient and traditional fining agent) only occasionally to aid in the clarification of the Red Knot wine as this product is tightly filtered at bottling. With the introduction of a high tech Cross-flow filter over 4 years ago egg white was no longer required to be used... With our computer recording systems even if 1 litre of older egg fined wine carried over to a younger blend the egg warning was applied."
[Barnivore note] Check older vintages of Red Knot for egg warning. The newer vintages (2009 and later, to play it safe) should be vegan-friendly. Just check the label.

Company email (February 2014):
"No animal products are used in our wines. All Shingleback wines are suitable for Vegans"

Company Email:
"I’ve attached a piece written by our winemaker Russ Rosner on our estate wines.  As you can see in that article, everything we make here on our estate is vegan- and vegetarian-friendly.  Our two blends, Evolution and Meditrina, do contain some wine made by other properties – so although we do try our hardest to source those pieces of our blends from wineries that we believe are not using animal products in their fining process, we cannot say with absolute certainty that those wines are 100% vegan diet friendly."

"all reds are suitable for vegans, white aren't (all are fined with milk products). So you're good to go with any of the red wines."

Company email (December 2011)
"Most of our reds are vegan friendly, all the whites unfortunately are out of the question. Available at the moment suitable are the following:
'10 Lust Collides

180301.product_name: Some Young Punks Passion has Red Lips 2013

notes:
Barnivore note (February 2014): Cockburn's is owned by Pernod Ricard, a major funder of bullfighting.

Company email (April 2013):
"Regarding your question we would like to inform that during the production of Dows Fine Ruby Port more precisely at the fining step it is only used Gelatine from porcine origin. Please note that  this is not an ingredient but a processing aid. No other product from animal source is used."

Company email (December 2011):
"In fact, some of the premium Ports (modern LBV, Reserves, Aged Tawnies) are fined with egg components. Those are suitable for vegetarians but not for vegans.

Almost all the standard Ports are fined with animal products (Ruby, Tawny, White).

Anyway, you can enjoy all the Bottle Matured Ports, those are not fined, clarified or filtered:

Vintage Port
Quinta Vintage Port
Bottle Aged Late Bottled Vintage (also designated as Bottle Matured Late Bottled Vintage)

Examples of very good Ports you can drink:
Dow’s Vintage Port
Warre’s Vintage Port
Cockburn’s Vintage Port
Graham’s Vintage Port
Dow’s Quinta do Bomfim Vintage Port
Warre’s Quinta da Cavadinha Vintage Port
Cockburn’s Quinta dos Canais Vintage Port
Graham’s Quinta dos Malvedos Vintage Port
Warre’s Bottle Aged LBV
Smith Woodhouse Bottle Matured LBV

Company email (February 2014): re: Museum Antique Tawny
"Unfortunately, since your last inquiry three years ago, our fortified wines have not yet reached vegan status, the current batches on the market still contain a small amount of gelatine. Although probably of little consolation, the residual amount is very small and still exceeds the reportable level of 2 mg/L, that is, 4 mg/L in our Antique Tawny and 8 mg/L in our Museum Muscat.

Although we ceased using animal products in our fortifieds in 2010, the nature of our production involves considerable backlog of stock, meaning it will be sometime before these wines reach a level that can be declared vegan-friendly - I'm sorry to say this will possibly take a further 2-3 years for our Antique Tawny and 4-5 years for our Museum Muscat.

Once they do become vegan/vegetarian-friendly, we will be including in our list of wines."

Note from Michelle (January 2013):
"I have discovered Yalumba wineries who make a large range of fabulous vegan wines." [PDF included showing vintages through 2011. Please contact them for a copy of the PDF file.}

From the company, January 2012:
"From 2011, all Yalumba and Hill-Smith Family Vineyard wines have been produced as vegan and vegetarian friendly. [PDF also included of past vintages]"

Editor's note: They sent a detailed PDF of all their vegan wines dated December 2010. Please contact them for your copy of the PDF. 

Company email:
"Thank you for taking the time to visit our website and enquire about our wines. We have several wines that are vegan-friendly and do not use any animal-derived fining agents, I have attached our list for you. Please note that not all vintages of the same wine are suitable for vegans (only the ones listed) and some of the older vintages may no longer be available in the stores. A few of these may not be available in the US.

The entire Oxford Landing range is now vegan-friendly as well as all of our Yalumba 2 litre red wine casks. Also, the entire Yalumba Y Series range starting from 2010 vintage is vegan (some Y Series wines from previous vintages were also vegan, you will see them on the list)."

Company email (June 2010):
"...I managed to obtain the Yalumba list of vegetarian- and vegan-friendly wines. See attached PDF"

Company email (February 2014):
"I have some very good news for you – our red wines are vegan friendly, with no fining or filtration."

Company email (February 2012):
"Reds are vegan friendly, most whites are too. Occasionally with the whites we may fine with skimmed milk powder or isinglass.  As a winery, all wines are made here."

6573101.product_name: d'Arenberg The High Trellis Cabernet Sauvignon 2011
